ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I learned about the climate system and how we know about the past as well as our predictions for the future. I enjoyed completing proofs to describe several different models for atmospheric and oceanic circulation.

My biggest takeaway from this course was an exposure to geophysical fluid dynamics in the context of understanding the climate. This course takes a quantitative approach which is lacking in many other courses.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: I found the lecture notes very helpful for following along with derivations.

The importance of reading the textbooks could be stressed more. The problem sets for undergrads should also contain more "exercise" style problems where we simply applying the concepts in addition to the longer project style questions. i.e., there could be more problem sets.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Climate dynamics is a challenging course for people who don't have much experience in math! I really enjoyed the course because I knew it was going to be difficult for me, so be prepared to challenge yourself if you haven't spent time doing math beyond multi-variable calc or computer programming. I found that I got a lot of practice in coding, which was really great for me, but might be a surprise to others. Professor Fedorov is a clear lecturer and is very helpful!

If you take this class, be sure to do the readings in the textbooks or else you won't get anything from the class. You use the Navier-Stokes equations without derivation, so it would be beneficial to have already taken a class in which they are derived. You should also be comfortable programming before starting the class. Either MatLab or Python with NumPy/SciPy/Matplotlib etc..
